0: we are part of a mips apm that consistently scores lower overall than if we were to report ourselves as a mips eligible clinician. we support the new app program so that we may submit ourselves, but since we work in ophthalmology, none of the measures used in the app measure set are relevant to us (table 36). we would like to see the same measure sets for mips to also be allowed in this program. if you continue with the measures listed in table 36, will there be a mav or some other protocol to determine if the measures are relevant to the ecs that submit under app?
2: thank you for the opportunity to provide public comments on the proposed rule regarding the medicare shared savings program quality reporting for 2021.  while i applaud the efforts to optimize quality reporting and move in the direction of low-burden, high-value measurement, the 2021 elimination of the web interface reporting mechanism will cause undue burden for medicare shared savings program aco participants. it is not unusual for acos to be comprised of participants on disparate electronic health records. the web interface tool allows for seamless pairing clinical data from various sites. elimination of this reporting mechanism in the short-term will create a reporting challenge for acos, and providers that comprise them, at an already dynamic time for healthcare organizations. if the goal remains to eliminate the web- interface mechanism, a prolonged phase-out will allow organizations to prepare.
3: ...in addition, the move to a 4th decile aco quality performance threshold could prove detrimental for organizations struggling in the readmission and unplanned admission for multiple chronic condition metrics. these vital measures of utilization practices are complex and require intensive shifts in practice patterns to gain measurable improvement. given the aforementioned strains on the current healthcare system, the timing is poor to institute more stringent provider performance thresholds for acos.
4: we respectfully decline from supporting cms proposals to make sweeping changes to how quality is assessed for the shared savings program and for the merit based incentive program (mips). aco’s are currently experiencing extreme stress due to the covid-19 pandemic and we are very concerned about our ability to cope with so many drastic changes. we urge cms to postpone making changes to the structure of the mssp quality measurement program.  acos’ have invested considerable resources into maintain high quality which is the cornerstone of value based care. the purpose and aim of quality measurement must be to improve patient care and not to fit a universal mold. acos’ should never be assessed the same as other apms and mips programs. cms should further refine quality measures to enhance patient care. cms created apms with specific goals in mind and we strongly feel that quality measures must be individually tailored for the needs of each apm.  the proposed approach lumps all apms and mips providers into one basket. historically acos have paralleled medicare advantage plans and aco quality standards are very similar to the medicare advantage program. we are also opposed to aco participants from selecting to report outside the aco since allowing the same could distort the performance of the risk bearing aco. we urge cms to continue the apm scoring standard at least until a proper aco centric replacement methodology can be agreed upon by all concerned stakeholders
5: pbaco is in favor of reducing administrative burden however we have significant concerns that the proposals, including limiting the number of performance based measures, puts acos at risk due to the dependence on the stability of fewer measures. over our seven years of program participation we have observed the mssp make errors and subsequent corrections to aco-11 in py2016 and py2017. furthermore, we have noticed remarkable nuances in the adjustment  3 methodology in our aco cahps measures. we support broad measurement across many measures where acos are insulated by the affects of errors, adjustments or other anomalies that can potentially erase an aco quality performance score and ultimately their shared savings multiplier and opportunity for annual revenue. we support that a larger set of quality measures smooths such anomalies, reduces overall aco risk and is worth any additional administrative burden.
6: cahps survey: we do not support combining the survey into one measure due our experience that certain measures can have anomalies including mssp errors, unpredictable adjustments and or other unexpected outcomes.  simply put, any benefit from reduced administration is far offset by the increased risk of the dependence on the accuracy and statistical stability of a single measure set. additionally, aco cahps cannot be compared to mips cahps. pbaco will have approximately 90,000 patients during 2021 and require a sample system that truly reflect large acos. the present system of 860 patients is too small a percentage of patients to predict the patient satisfaction scores with a 95% confidence level. we propose increasing the pbaco sample size to 2,000 patients as opposed to the mips-cahps requirement of 60,000 patients which is impractical to administer and very expensive.
7: present gpro measures: we strongly disagree with canceling the cms web interface. it has been our experience that ecqm adoption at practices is less than 25%. pbaco has over 30 emr systems with various capabilities as well as a dedicated team of three aco employees to facility education, optimization and implementation of our provider ehr systems. some emrs are not ready to collect ecqms intuitively and providers must go through convoluted workflows to report ecqms. secondly providers will have to report data from other payers, in addition to medicare as many ehrs do not have the capability to report by payer. this distorts the aco’s medicare specific quality performance reporting. it is our opinion that the various ehr certification should refine and standardize workflows for ecqms which have been tested in the field and which do not increase administrative burden for providers. it is our observation that the respective ehrs have various workflows for the same ecqms and have not been pervasively implemented. the gap to achieve effective and efficient implementation of ecqms is still large and too large to justify the replacement of cms web interface quality submissions.  we do not agree that the proposed three quality measures are adequate to measure provider performance and to provide adequate insolation from the statistical risks of dependency on such few measures. we do agree that the domain score of 50% should not change with the proposed rule however we strongly recommend reinstating more and essential aco measures. please refer to table 36p. we have added back a) colorectal cancer screening, b) breast cancer screening, depression screening and follow-up, influenza immunization, and pneumococcal vaccinations. these measures are the core measures in an acos quality performance. pbaco has observed favorable outcomes from the training and implementation of depression screening and follow-up. we would like to reintroduce pneumococcal vaccinations as an important measure to reduce hospitalizations due to various forms of pneumonia. additionally, during covid-19 patients will have higher immunity levels to pneumonia caused bronchial infections. along with the reintroduction of these measures we request that the domain score for measures related to the wi remain stay constant at 50%.
8: claims based measures: we disagree with the proposed increased weight of the claims-based measures to 33% of the total score from 25%. we propose the reinstatement of ambulatory sensitive condition and maintain the total domain weight for claims based measures at 25%. essentially, we are proposing no change to these measures. we further caution cms that the reduction of claims based measures and the increase in domain weight can have unintended consequences and the introduction of risks to acos. please consider the mssp errors and subsequent corrections to aco-11 in py2016 and py2017. we believe that these errors set a precedent that errors can happen and that broadly reduces an acos ability to smooth or defend itself from such errors. considering that any given measure will have significantly more individual significance, errors, like those that occurred in py2016 or py2017 have a much higher chance of completely erasing an aco quality performance score and ultimately their shared savings multiplier and their opportunity for annual revenue.
9: removing the cms web interface reporting mechanism  it took several years of education and technological investment for pbaco to effectively and efficiently report quality using the cms web interface. eliminating this option will drastically increase pbacos cost for quality reporting due to the various emr vendors’ ecqm annual registry fees.  we also have significant concerns regarding the lack of uniformity and ability to be compared to peers with the way ecqms are collected today. today’s emrs report ecqms for all beneficiaries including aco and non-aco beneficiaries and medicare and non-medicare beneficiaries. we believe that this is a significant programmatic downside where current performance is medicare, incentive and demographic specific. in additional to the introduction of potentially irrelevant performance measurement, the variety and inconsistency of demographics by provider may potentially distort the performance measurement and the ability to accurately compare providers. it is possible that our payer specific data use agreements do not cover all demographics and we may run into legal conflicts with insurance companies. pbaco is in favor of less administrative burden but requests that cms continues to pursue other options including more widespread adoption of the cms web interface. it is our proposal that cms continues to run ecqms in parallel with the cms web interface and monitors the results. currently, pbaco is reporting quality for 2,792 patients. under the proposed rule we will be forced to report quality on 60,000 aco patients across dozens of disparate systems at a significant financial expense.  aco quality must be targeted to acos and their aco peers and cannot be compared to providers with disparate value based contract implementation, payor mix or demographic mix.
10: pbaco opposes the removal of pay-for-reporting when new measures are introduced. acos need time to educate on, build and implement workflows for new quality measures. we urge cms to not finalize this approach and instead maintain the pay-for-reporting for the first year introduced to acos in their initial performance year, as well as new quality measures when they are introduced or significantly changed. pbaco urges cms to utilize a scoring approach that is more like the current domain-based scoring approach instead of using an all-or-nothing approach as proposed. we do not see the correlation of value delivered by aco providers and the way that they are scored with an all-ornothing approach. we find it difficult to state that a 20th percentile performer receives 0 points or delivers 0 value while a 30th percentile performer receives 1.2 points or 55% of the value. we believe that further promoting this all-or-nothing approach will unjustly disconnect the correlation from the value that medicare beneficiaries and the medicare trust fund receive from status performance of acos and discourage providers from participation. one side effect of increased aco participation is improved performance in aco quality measures and the increase of the performance thresholds for percentile scoring. the all-or-nothing proposal of the 40th percentile required threshold allows that “good” performance of previous years may be classified as 0 performance in future years. we expect that this is an enormous risk to the sustainability and the perceived fairness of the program by providers. we urge cms to move away from allor-nothing scoring replace with gradual scoring, consistent with the value delivered by aco providers to medicare beneficiaries and the medicare trust fund.
11: alternative proposal allowing aco selection of quality measures proposals: cms seeks comment on an alternative approach that acos could use in the event “the three measures acos are required to actively report on are not applicable to their beneficiary population.” in this case, the aco could choose to opt out of the app and report to mips as an apm entity selecting more appropriate measures available under mips. cms does not include any further details regarding how cms would determine if the three required measures were not applicable to the aco. comments: pbaco opposes this approach to provide acos the option of selecting alternative quality measures to report. pbaco cannot contemplate any instances where primary care physicians will want to select alternate measures. this proposal further adds confusion and instability to the quality reporting process for acos.
12: awarding the higher of the 2019 or 2020 aco quality score and cahps changes for 2020 due to covid-19 phe proposals: cms seeks comment on an option that would provide acos the higher of their 2019 or 2020 quality scores for py 2020 due to the impact of the covid-19 phe, so long as acos fully report on quality measures in 2020. additionally, due to the negative impact of covid-19 on sample size and performance scores, cms proposes to remove the requirement for acos to field a cahps for acos survey for py 2020. instead, cms proposes to provide automatic full points for each of the cahps survey measures within the patient/caregiver experience domain for py 2020. comments: pbaco is in agreement with this proposal. we have observed that the impact of covid-19 or other extreme and uncontrollable circumstances can vary significantly by market. we support that the quality scores from an unaffected period is relevant and likely consistent with the expected performance of the impacted period absent an emergency. this method was formerly been implemented by medicare advantage, referenced on page 8 below in the 2019 draft policy; https://www.cms.gov/medicare/prescription-drugcoverage/prescriptiondrugcovgenin/downloads/2019-technical-notes-preview-2.pdf we also support the removal of the cahps survey for py 2020 and awarding 100% score for this category due to the covid-19 emergency.
13: quality measure specification changes proposals: cms proposes several notable measure specification changes for the cms web interface quality measures for 2021. cms proposes to add denominator exclusions for advanced illness and frailty for the breast cancer screening and colorectal cancer screening measures. cms also proposes to update specifications for certain cms web interface measures to allow telehealth encounters as eligible encounters.  comments: pbaco urges cms to keep the current measure set for 2021 and to not make any changes that will bring in instability to the mssp. particularly on a year of public health emergency, we do not think that sweeping changes will be good for the program at this time. we have made significant labor and technology investments to educate on, optimize and implement the current cms web interface and we urge cms to consider more observation, particularly during this public health emergency compared to proposing radical programmatic changes that may further disrupt a currently displace primary care physician community. pbaco supports cms proposals to add denominator exclusions for advanced illness and frailty for the breast cancer and colorectal cancer screening measures, as previously advocated for by naacos. these important exclusions will ensure unnecessary care is not provided to patients with advanced illness.  pbaco urges cms to keep the reporting period for influenza immunizations unchanged as they are still relevant during the public health emergency. pbaco pcps are seeking very high adherence to influenza immunizations through 2021.
14: adjustments to the mssp extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy proposals: cms proposes to make changes to the quality portion of the mssp extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy for acos to align with the proposed changes to introduce a new app for acos. for py 2021 and subsequent years, cms proposes to provide an aco affected by an extreme and uncontrollable circumstance with the higher of its own quality score or a score equal to the 40th percentile mips quality performance category score. cms also proposes to use the quarter four list of assigned beneficiaries to determine the portion of patients affected by the extreme and uncontrollable circumstance. in addition, cms seeks comment on a potential alternative extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy for py 2022 and subsequent years. specifically, cms proposes to adjust the amount of shared savings determined for affected acos that complete quality reporting but do not meet the quality performance standard, or that are unable to complete quality reporting. under this alternative approach, cms would determine shared savings for an affected aco by multiplying the maximum possible shared savings the aco would be eligible to receive based on its financial performance and track (or payment model within a track) by the percentage of the total months in the performance year affected by an extreme and uncontrollable circumstance and the percentage of the aco’s assigned beneficiaries who reside in an area affected by an extreme and uncontrollable circumstance. comments: pbaco does not support cms making further changes to the mssp extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy. extensive changes have been made to mssp extreme and uncontrollable policies in the last two years along with supplemental changes due to covid-19. as noted above, we do not support cms proposals to change aco quality assessments, and therefore we also do not support the proposed changes to the mssp extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy to align with the new app proposals.
15: pbaco supports updating the definition of primary care codes used for mssp assignment. adding these 9 codes for “e-visits,” chronic care management, and principal care management to the mssp assignment methodology will definitely be a plus to the assignment methodology. we also appreciate cms’s desire to ensure that patients are attributed to providers from whom they receive their primary care services. therefore, we support excluding advance care planning services from mssp assignment when billed in an inpatient setting and excluding professional services furnished by fqhcs or rhcs when delivered in a snf. pbaco supports naacos recommendations that cms use a two-year assignment window for mssp to account for potential variations in attribution in 2020 and 2021. therefore, patient visits from 2019 and 2020 should be considered for acos’ assignment lists regardless if acos choose prospective attribution or retrospective attribution. we believe that a 2 year assignment window will mitigate the effects of covid-19 on provider performance measurement and provider performance based payments through the mssp.
16: exclusion from aco assignment of certain services reported by fqhcs or rhcs when furnished in skilled nursing facilities (85 fr 50246) nachc supports the policy change that cms describes, which would ensure that when fqhc clinicians participating in accountable care organizations (acos) furnish primary care services to individuals in snfs (cpt codes 99304-99318), those services would be excluded for purposes of beneficiary assignment to an aco. as we understand, this ensures parity between fqhc practitioners and physicians and practitioners who practice in other settings with respect to this issue. we therefore support cms’ proposed implementing amendment at 42 c.f.r. § 425.400(c)(1)(v).
17: we ask medicare to consider a no risk option for acos that are made up of privately practicing physicians. we think there is value to medicare shared savings program for acos with upside only risk. there are privately practicing physicians who are committed to actively engage in the shared savings program work to innovate and improve healthcare processes, but either cannot afford to personally take on risk, or because the margins are small in the aco financials, even a small amount of risk to too much for them to bear. we have physicians raising grave concerns about being required to take on risk. as you are aware, physician lead acos historically outperform hospital lead acos. upside only acos generate shared savings. we are aware medicare wants to push all aco to high risk, because the current high risk acos tends to generate greater degree of savings. at this point, high risk acos are self-selected. if all acos were forced into high risk, medicare cannot ensure the same degree of savings will occur. a steady amount of shavings generated by upside only acos brings value to the medicare system, continues to drive improvements and is potentially more sustainable long term. does medicare want short term gains or long term gains? personally, we think it is better to have steady long term benefits for the program.
18: change from domain based approach to an all or nothing approach - we disagree with these changes and request medicare continue with the domain based approach. these changes are substantial. why does medicare want to make it more difficult for acos to attain shared savings? from my personal perspective, this is counter intuitive. shared savings is the carrot to make change happen. the threshold for receiving a percentage of savings should be reasonably obtainable. physician lead acos utilize a significant amount of the shared savings to drive innovation, care coordination and to support the practices to drive improvement. making the threshold too high will make the program no longer financially feasible for the physicians to participate. if physician lead acos consolidates with large entities to manage the acos, then medicare will suffer from the natural outcome of large consolidation, which is standardization. standardization reduces the amount of innovation that occurs and we will have another version of the medicare advantage system. a different thought on encouraging change is to have a step process for quality measures and percentage of savings which can be done for upside only acos. example: acos can choose to go with the current 23 measures for up to 50% of the shares savings of which they will receive savings based on their overall quality score. the alternative is to move to the proposed 6 measures report through the web interface and have the opportunity for 70% of shared savings, because moving to a limited measure set of outcome based measures has greater risk and challenges.
19: quality performance standard: we request to keep the minimum quality achievement at 30% per measure not 40%. some measures are very challenging and the aco has limited control of all of the various healthcare delivery components to the measure, such as all cause readmissions and unplanned admissions. for example, it has taken us several years to have the local hospitals provide the aco access to the discharge lists for our patients. since it can take time to build and educate on why working with the aco is of value, we request medicare to maintain the current minimum of 30%.   a second example to take into consideration, our aco suffered a substantial decline in mammography rates, because a regional mobile mammography provider went out of business. this was a major provider of mammography services for our aco patients and is no longer available for our region. they were the only provider. now we have substantial issues with transportation to obtain mammography screening. issues like this are unpredictable and if flexibility is removed from the system, the aco could suffer significantly. a third example is when acos take on new physician practices. even when new practices have experience in working with quality measures and risk, the aco environment is different than the medicare advantage experience and does not translate to success. the aco environment has a different process and cadence that must be taught. if an aco takes on too many new practices, this can create a significant challenge in improving quality measures year over year. acos need time to adapt and find new solutions for unpredictable events and taking on new physician practices. thus, cms should take these types of factors into consideration, when evaluating aco performance year over year. acos will not always be able to have ever improving numbers.
20: changing from 23 to 6 measures – we recommend a more gradual change and to retain some of the current office based measures such as vaccinations, mammograms and colorectal screening, which have preventative health value. we understand the desire for medicare to move to the 6 identified outcome measures. for acos to be successful at such a limited data set, we need to make substantial changes in our current focus. the other component, we need to know the benchmarks for the 6 proposed measures. will cms take into consideration patient compliance? some patients take longer to archive care goals, while some patients never will. how will cms accommodate for these patients for whom the physician is doing their best to assist the patient, yet the patient is unable or unwilling to archive measure goals? in addition, is cms taking into account the aco patient mix with the 6 identified quality measures? do the acos have the same relative volume of diabetes and hypertension? if not, how will this be addressed? if an aco has 10% of their patient population that is diabetic, it is very different than an aco that has 60%. cms should clarify if the outcome measures chosen are representative for all acos.
21: moving from web based reporting to mips (registry/emr based) reporting – we disagree with the move. we request cms continue with the web based reporting as an option for acos. it is very important for acos to be reporting on our attributed patients for quality scoring. as an aco of independent practicing physicians, we do not have the right to the full patient list of our physicians. we are gravely concerned. the aco cannot impact the quality metrics for the non-aco patients. it is not fair or reasonable to measure an aco’s quality based on nonattributed patients.
22: removing pay for reporting – we disagree with this change to the shared savings program. all new acos should have 1-2 years to learn how to work together to determine where they are on the quality metrics, and to implement improvement process. improvement process takes time. in addition, if cms makes a substantive change to a quality measure, we should have 1-2 years of reporting to learn the changes, implement improvement process and evaluate the success or failure of our improvement activities.
23: compliance with quality performance standard – we are concerned with the proposal to terminate an aco if they have 2 bad years. we are also concerned that medicare is not taking into account the rapid cycle changes in which they expect acos to adapt. if medicare wants to make a more stringent compliance standard, then medicare needs to provide a long steady state (no system changes for 5 years). under a long steady state, a stricter compliance program will make sense. under a rapid change environment, we recommend medicare have a compliance standard that offers more opportunities for education, learning and corrective action plans. if medicare chooses to implement the compliance standard for termination of acos that have 2 years of poor compliance, the termination should be limited to gross negligence. in addition, this standard should not be retroactive.
24: extreme and uncontrollable circumstance – we agree and support for medicare to keep this process in place. we also support the recommendations for aco to receive full points for each of the cahps survey measure within the patient/caregiver experience domain for 2020. we also support making 2020 a pay for reporting year to allow the aco to continue to focus on quality while facing the unprecedented events of the public health emergency.
25: definition of pcp – we support medicare’s proposal to include the telehealth codes as part of the definition of primary care services.
26: while bswh supports the expanded list of assignment codes, bswh has significant concerns with the multitude of cms mssp quality reporting and measure changes and do not support these policies for finalization. additional time is needed to analyze these proposals, especially relative to the ongoing pandemic. providers have limited bandwidth to make the significant operational adjustments, as many staff have been reallocated for different pandemic purposes. this is especially true given that this proposed rule may be finalized with as little as 30-days for acos to implement these changes. additionally, cms does not provide enough information for bswh to understand how these changes may impact our performance in the program. while we appreciate cms’ desire to reduce burden by aligning program standards and reducing reporting requirements, we strongly urge cms to delay these proposals for at least another one year and continue engagement with providers and association to understand the best path forward for transition the mssp.
28: bswh has serious concerns with cms’ proposal to establish 2021 benchmarks using the same year’s data. this will not provide acos the opportunity to understand and make improvements on their performance. furthermore, we do not support cms making changes to its extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policies at this time, given acos are still working under the current policy during the pandemic. abrupt changes in policy, like reporting requirements for covid-19, have been difficult for providers to adjust to. while we appreciate the need for program alignment, these policy changes should take place after the pandemic, once the totality of information and learnings can be assessed.
30: bswh appreciates cms’s proposal to allow review of qp calculations and we urge the agency to expand this opportunity to improve transparency in how these calculations are made. acos spend millions of dollars in start-up costs and ongoing operational expenses to fund key initiatives and assume risk. the advanced apm incentive is very important to fund these activities. it is imperative that as cms implements macra the agency provides more transparency on how qp calculations are completed as well as enough information for acos to recreate their qp scores to verify their validity. unfortunately, acos continue to report inaccuracies with the information displayed on the qpp portal (lookup tool). providing a meaningful opportunity for reviewing qp calculations and determinations is essential to building provider confidence in how cms is managing the important transition to value. acos rely on cms and its contractors to execute complex program methodologies and operations, such as determining qp scores. these methodologies and calculations are essential to the qpp and determine whether an apm entity receives an advanced apm bonus. however, these methodologies and their corresponding calculations are not fully disclosed. while cms shares its general approaches, and acos do their best to replicate cms’s work, the agency does not provide the level of detail needed for acos to make their own precise calculations. cms should be fully transparent with its methodologies and calculations, and acos should be able to replicate them on their own. we urge cms to share the exact algorithms for these important methodologies and calculations.
32: medicare shared savings program cms proposes major structural changes to the way mssp accountable care organizations (acos) are measured and assessed on quality. for 2021 and future performance years, cms proposes to sunset the current approach of quality measurement for mssp acos and replace it with a new app to better align with the qpp. cms also notes that many acos are high performers under the current structure and the agency believes it is appropriate to require a higher standard of care in order for acos to continue to share in any savings they achieve. cms also notes the agency believes holding acos to a higher standard is in line with cms goals of incentivizing value-based care and driving the medicare system to greater value and quality. notably, the new app would include fewer measures and a higher minimum attainment standard, which is the threshold that acos would be evaluated on to be eligible to share in savings earned.  while commonspirit supports the concept of streamlining and focusing quality measure sets, we are not confident that the proposed measure set best suited to advancing the mssp’s goals. we certainly appreciate cms’s goal of aligning methodologies across programs, but we do not support cms proposals to make such sweeping changes to how aco quality is assessed, how quality data is reported, and how acos are evaluated on quality for mssp. further, these changes come amidst the unprecedented covid-19 phe. the timing of these changes is very concerning as acos continue to deal with the uncertainty that the phe is bringing to the health care industry. at a minimum, commonspirit urges cms to postpone making any structural changes to the way aco quality is assessed or reported until at least 2022. finally, while these proposed changes align more with the way individual clinicians and groups are scored in merit-based incentive payment system, it is a farther departure from the way cms assesses other non-fee-for-service providers, such as medicare advantage. therefore, this effort at alignment is a step backward for acos and those committed to value.  quality improvement is a cornerstone of the aco model. in addition to reducing spending, acos must meet certain quality performance standards to be eligible to receive shared savings payments. acos continue to improve quality year over year, which improves patient care and helps to control costs. it is critical that cms policies to evaluate aco quality are fair, appropriate and accurately reflect the work acos undertake to improve patient care. cms’s proposals to change the way aco quality is assessed, reported and scored for the purpose of shared savings calculation are significant and more feedback should be collected before moving forward with such drastic changes.
33: avera urees cms to work with the national association of acos fnaacosl and other stakeholders to make changes to the current quality measure performance evaluation criteria and measure sets for acos to further refine the measures and criteria appropriate for a group of providers who are responsible for total cost of care for the populations they serve. additionally, avera opposes cms' proposal to reduce the number of clinical quality measures for acos to three measures. avera requests that cms work with stakeholders to identjfylh6 most approerjate set of measures for acos.
34: dear administrator verma, our accountable care organization (aco) writes to you to urge cms to not finalize the quality proposals released in the 2021 medicare physician fee schedule rule. the changes come at a very challenging time as our aco and the health care industry as a whole continue to navigate the great uncertainty resulting from the covid-19 global health pandemic. we urge cms not to implement changes to the quality program until a future performance year and continue to work with acos to adapt the quality measurement and assessment process. these changes are significant and touch every aspect of quality improvement efforts from reporting quality data, tracking measure performance, and how acos are evaluated and scored for both the medicare shared savings program (mssp) and merit-based incentive payment system (mips). there are multiple concerns with the proposed aco quality changes. first, replacing the current domain-based quality scoring approach with an all or nothing standard is a significant change that will have a big impact on aco performance. secondly, drastically reducing the number of quality measures from 23 to six de-emphasizes quality and will create a performance standard that may not be truly representative of an aco's actual quality improvement efforts. thirdly, abruptly removing the web interface as a reporting mechanism will have a big impact on acos' ability to get credit for their true quality efforts. cms should continue to offer the web interface as an option and over time allow additional reporting options to those acos who would be ready to implement, such as registry or electronic health record (ehr) reporting. additionally, moving to the alternative reporting options cms has provided through the proposed apm performance pathway (app) would cause many acos to have to pay for registries and/or ehr upgrades and dashboards to capture the correct data to be able to report to cms. finally, there are remaining questions regarding how the aco would report the data for non-medicare and non-aco patient data, which is required when reporting using a registry or ehr. this could cause acos to have to revisit contracts and could raise legal concerns as the aco does not typically have access to non-aco patient data. finally, we also have deep concerns with the uncertainty of how the impact of covid-19 will be measured and calculated for the aco 2020 performance year. the cms proposed consideration is to exclude all member-months and expenses incurred by attributed beneficiaries with a positive covid-19 diagnosis. while this accounts for covid expenditures, there are additional factors that have impacted our acos. we ask that the proposal also consider the added challenges in retaining aco attribution due to the drop in primary care visit volume and consider the challenges of recruiting additional aco participants for the 2021 performance year as community providers are focused on managing through the healthcare crisis. these two factors will contribute to a reduction in final attribution for the 2020 performance year and reduced potential attribution and participation in the 2021 performance year. acos are committed to providing high quality care to our patients and quality improvement is at the core of what we do. making these sweeping changes at this challenging time will disadvantage our aco and we urge cms to consider this feedback in drafting the final rule. sincerely, mallory cary, aco director texas panhandle clinical partners aco, llc 367 s. gulph road king of prussia, pa 19406
35: finally, we also have deep concerns with the uncertainty of how the impact of covid-19 will be measured and calculated for the aco 2020 performance year. the cms proposed consideration is to exclude all member-months and expenses incurred by attributed beneficiaries with a positive covid-19 diagnosis. while this accounts for covid expenditures, there are additional factors that have impacted our acos. we ask that the proposal also consider the added challenges in retaining aco attribution due to the drop in primary care visit volume and consider the challenges of recruiting additional aco participants for the 2021 performance year as community providers are focused on managing through the healthcare crisis. these two factors will contribute to a reduction in final attribution for the 2020 performance year and reduced potential attribution and participation in the 2021 performance year. acos are committed to providing high quality care to our patients and quality improvement is at the core of what we do. making these sweeping changes at this challenging time will disadvantage our aco and we urge cms to consider this feedback in drafting the final rule. sincerely, mallory cary, aco director texas panhandle clinical partners aco, llc 367 s. gulph road king of prussia, pa 19406
40: quality measures in the medicare shared savings program under the proposed rule, cms proposes to replace the current quality performance structure for accountable care organizations (acos) participating in the medicare shared savings program (mssp) by reducing the quality measures an aco must report from 23 to six and removing the pay-forreporting year. although this proposal retains several of important quality measures tied to serious chronic conditions, such as controlling high blood pressure, depression screening, and diabetes control, it eliminates the measure for colorectal cancer screening. at guardant health, we believe liquid biopsy is at the center of transforming cancer care by unlocking data that will help patients at all stages of the disease. while we have made great strides to help patients with advanced cancer, our vision since inception has been to detect cancer early, when patient survival rates can be impacted most. we see great promise in leveraging liquid biopsy to increase cancer screening rates, which is why it is crucial that cms continue to prioritize metrics such as nqf #0034 for colorectal cancer screening.
41: cms proposal: cms has proposed that the app will be mandatory for mssp acos for quality demonstration, starting in 2021. cms has also proposed that apps may be reported at the individual clinician, group tin, or apm entity level. (see proposed rule, p. 50230). practice comment: the practice supports cms’ proposal and encourages the agency to finalize as proposed. the practice believes that the transition to app measurement will reduce burden by limiting the number of measures an aco needs to attest to three. the practice also believes that the flexibility to report as an individual, a group tin, or an apm entity gives sufficient options to successfully report in cy 2021.
43: cms proposal: cms has proposed removing the cms web interface as a collection type and submission type beginning in cy 2021. (see proposed rule, p. 50288). practice comment: the practice supports this proposal and encourages cms to finalize as proposed. the removal of cms web interface will significantly support cms in its goal to transition to digital quality measures. the practice also believes it will reduce burden for providers as it will reduce the number of reportable measures from ten to six. additionally,  seema verma october 5, 2020 page 7 7 c:\users\vdevassy\documents\2021mpfs.docx former users of the cms web interface will now begin reporting all payer cqm data as other mips providers currently do. the practice believes this will enlarge the populations within these groups who are receiving the benefit of quality metrics such as depression screening and pneumococcal vaccination status, rather than practices focusing those wellness measures solely on medicare ffs patients.
44: we are proposing to revise the shared savings program quality performance standard effective for performance year 2021 and subsequent performance years. this proposed revision would align the shared savings program quality performance standard with the proposed app under the quality payment program as participants in the shared savings program would be required to report quality for purposes of the shared savings program via the app. nextgen healthcare believes this timeline (complicated by a lack of clear requirements) presents challenges. we request more details and suggest the use of an existing submission methodology would simplify participation. our trade association the ehr association has previously requested a minimum of 18 months for development and implementation.
45: as discussed in section iv.a.3.c.(1)(b) of this proposed rule, we are proposing to sunset the cms web interface measures as a collection type for groups and virtual groups with 25 or more eligible clinicians starting with the 2021 performance period. nextgen healthcare supports this proposal, which focuses on electronically reported measures rather than abstraction, in alignment with cms’ interoperability initiatives. switching submission mechanisms and quality measure specifications represents a significant change for practices that have historically reported via the cms web interface, so we encourage cms to consider feedback from clinicians and recommend a transition period of at least one year.
46: mips quality category. for cy 2021 quality reporting, cms would mostly carry over cy 2020 reporting requirements and scoring approaches. however, cms proposes three notable changes – the removal of the web interface reporting option, the incorporation of telehealth into consumer assessment of healthcare providers and systems (cahps) survey questions and sampling methodology, and a revised benchmarking approach specific to the cy 2021 performance period. the aha opposes cms’s proposal to eliminate the web interface reporting option from the mips program. we also oppose its removal from the medicare shared  seema verma october 5, 2020 page 20 of 25 savings program (mssp). we refer the agency to the mssp section of this letter for additional details.
47: quality measure set. while the aha supports the concept of streamlining and focusing quality measure sets, we are not confident that the measure set cms has proposed for the mssp is best suited to advancing the program’s goals. we urge cms to obtain further stakeholder input before finalizing these changes. cms’s proposed policy would require mssp aco participants to report on the same six measures that are proposed for the new mips app. we acknowledge that versions of these six measures already are used in the mssp program. however, as we note below, cms has proposed a significant change to how the data would be reported by eliminating the web interface reporting option, which would significantly affect how aco performance is benchmarked in the coming years. as a result, mssp participants do not know how they would fare using this specific configuration of measures, which is especially alarming given that cms also proposes to eliminate any pay-for-reporting years (also discussed below).  additionally, the proposed changes to the measure set come on the heels of significant changes to the structure of the mssp program as cms implemented its new pathways approach. the implementation of drastic changes to measurement as acos continue to adapt to the new program structure is enormously disruptive to acos, especially as they, too, grapple with the significant impacts of the covid-19 phe. instead of finalizing the changes now, we encourage cms to work with stakeholders to review the entirety of the current aco measure set, and use their input to help identify which measures are the best candidates for elimination. the agency could consider using input from the measure applications partnership (map) as a part of its upcoming cycle to obtain multi-stakeholder input on these changes. again, the aha strongly supports the concept of streamlining measure sets; however, we fear the potential for significant unintended consequences if the mssp measure sets are adopted too precipitously.
48: removal of web interface reporting. the aha does not support the removal of the web interface reporting option for acos at this time. the web interface has been used by acos since the mssp’s inception to report data on non-claims based measures used in the program. the web interface collects data on medicare beneficiaries participating in the mssp, and has a set of data collection and attribution approaches associated with it. however, cms proposes to eliminate it because its use outside of the mssp program is limited, and the agency is seeking to bring the mssp quality measurement approach into closer alignment with the mips. while we appreciate the potential benefits of greater alignment between programs, there are profound differences between how data are submitted in the “regular” mips program and how they are reported by acos using the web interface. in the first place, the data collection types that would now be available to acos – ehrs, qualified registries and qualified clinical data registries – all require data to be collected on an allpayer basis, and not simply on medicare beneficiaries. for a program that is called the medicare shared savings program, and is intended to improve the care for medicare beneficiaries, we question the appropriateness of including all-payer data. furthermore, allowing the use of multiple different reporting options in the mssp could have significant impacts on measure benchmarks. there are differences in the measure specifications among each of these reporting mechanisms; it is possible, even when reporting on the same measure title, to receive different scores. for that reason, when cms calculates performance benchmarks in the mips program, it creates separate benchmarks for each data collection type. yet, cms does not address in this rule how it intends to reconcile any potential performance differences among acos that may stem from differences in data collection types. unless and until cms can address the two issues above, it is not appropriate to remove the web interface reporting option. at a minimum, we urge the agency to delay removal of the reporting mechanism until cy 2022 at the very earliest.
49: increase to quality performance standard. the aha does not support cms’s proposal to increase the quality performance standard for acos at this time. we certainly appreciate cms’s intent to “raise the bar” on aco performance. however, cms proposes to require acos to achieve the 40th percentile of performance as compared to all mips quality category scores, as opposed to only aco scores. as noted in the previous sections of this letter, there are numerous unresolved questions about whether it is appropriate to include non-medicare patients in aco quality performance assessment, and whether the inclusion of multiple data collection types would maintain equitable performance comparisons across all acos. until those issues are resolved, it would be inappropriate to raise the performance threshold.
50: elimination of pay-for-reporting. the aha opposes cms’s proposal to eliminate pay-for-reporting for first year of mssp participation, as well as pay-for-reporting  for newly added or significantly revised measures. for first-time participants in the mssp, it takes significant resources to learn measure specifications, assess baseline performance and implement workflow changes – it and otherwise – necessary for accurately capturing and improving quality performance. furthermore, when cms makes significant changes to existing measure specifications, providers must make several of these same adaptations. given that cms now scores mssp acos on improvement over time, it is essential for cms to establish an accurate performance baseline. pay-for-reporting periods give acos the opportunity to ramp up their measurement and improvement capabilities in a sustainable fashion before their shared savings or losses are tied to quality performance.
52: transition to the app and removal of web interface reporting option gnyha opposes the transition of mssp quality reporting to the app. while this proposal would reduce the burden on acos in terms of the overall number of measures required for submission, it would impose new burdens because cms would discontinue the web interface reporting option. instead, acos would be required to report quality information through one of the allowable methods under the apm app, either through a registry or direct submission via electronic health records (ehrs). acos have invested significantly in developing processes to allow for the submission of quality data. switching to either of the app reporting options would require significant investments in workflow changes, new infrastructure such as registries, and/or adaptation of ehrs to comply with electronic clinical quality measure standards. not only would this impose significant financial and operational burdens on acos, the required operational changes could not be completed by the start of the 2021 performance year. as with all health care providers, acos are currently struggling with numerous challenges and significant uncertainty due to the covid-19 pandemic. it would be irresponsible to implement such a drastic change at this time. furthermore, the quality submission options proposed by cms do not allow for quality reporting and measurement specific to only aco attributed beneficiaries. therefore, acos would be assessed for quality performance on non-aco assigned beneficiaries. gnyha believes that aco quality performance should be limited, to the extent possible, to the defined cohort of beneficiaries that are assigned to the aco. therefore, to avoid placing unnecessary burden on providers and to ensure that quality measurement reflects the true performance of each aco, gnyha recommends that cms withdraw its proposal to remove the web interface reporting option.
53: revision of the quality performance standard cms proposes to raise the quality performance standard (the minimum threshold for an aco to be eligible for shared savings) from the 30th percentile for at least one measure in each domain to requiring a mips  quality performance score at or above the 40th percentile across all mips categories. this change makes it more difficult for acos to earn shared savings. as mentioned above, the covid-19 pandemic has caused significant uncertainty among acos. while we applaud cms for its efforts to address the potential impact on the various pay-for-performance programs for 2020, we believe such a major change to the mssp quality performance standard is premature. the long-term impact of covid-19 on medicare beneficiaries and ultimately its impact on quality measurement is still unclear. for example, cms’s proposed rule impact analysis is based on 2018 data and therefore may not be representative of average quality performance post covid-19. we urge cms to postpone these changes until both cms and the provider community have been able to assess the impact of the pandemic on quality scores.
54: medicare shared savings program cms proposals cms proposes to revise the medicare shared savings program (mssp) quality performance standard to align with a proposed alternative payment model performance pathway (app) under the quality  payment program merit-based incentive payment system (mips). the proposal would reduce the number of measures acos are scored on from 23 to six; acos would only need to actively report on three of the six. the agency also proposes to eliminate the cms web interface, beginning in 2021. finally, cms proposes to change the quality performance standard, from the 30th percentile on one measure in each domain, to the 40th percentile across all mips quality performance category scores.  cleveland clinic response while cleveland clinic directionally supports cms’s changes and appreciates the agency’s attention to reducing the reporting burden on acos, we are concerned that cms’s proposal is too much, too fast – especially in the context of the covid-19 pandemic. while the agency’s proposal would reduce the amount of reporting required of an aco, it also would require acos to quickly pivot from established quality measurement and reporting processes, even as many of them are still in the midst of responding to the pandemic. specifically, cleveland clinic aco meets its reporting obligations via the web interface (as did over 98 percent of acos in 2019, as the agency itself noted), and this method of reporting is sufficiently integrated into our workflows as to be nearly automated. in contrast, elimination of the web interface would require us to quickly transition to reporting via a different mechanism. further, we would need time to understand the differences in measures specifications between the web interface and our chosen reporting mechanism, and identify and adjust to any potential impact on performance. cms itself notes the potential burden associated with making this transition. we ask that the agency postpone implementation of this proposal until at least the 2022 performance period, in order to provide sufficient time for acos identify and plan for a new reporting mechanism.
55: medicare shared savings program 15 issue: alternative payment model (amp) performance pathway (app) for mips apms and mssp acos – proposed measure set cms is proposing to implement the apm performance pathway (app) for mips apms and mssp acos for the 2021 performance year. the agency intends for this change to reduce burden, align measures across programs and address high priority areas for quality improvement. cms proposes a smaller measure set, a decrease from 23 measures to six, including two hospital admissions and readmissions measures:  hospital-wide, 30-day, all-cause unplanned readmission (hwr) rate for mips eligible clinician groups  risk standardized, all-cause unplanned admissions for multiple chronic conditions for acos  recommendation: bcbsa opposes the inclusion of these two hospital admissions and readmissions measures in the proposed measure set. we urge cms to align the proposed measure set with the core quality measures collaborative (cqmc) and its work on the accountable care organization/patient-centered medical home (aco/pcmh) measure set.  rationale: bcbsa supports cms’ alignment with the cqmc aco/pcmh core measure set aiming to: identify high-value, high-impact, evidence-based measures; align measures across public and private payers; and reduce the burden of measurement by eliminating low-value metrics, redundancies and inconsistencies in measure specifications and quality measure reporting requirements across payers.  cqmc membership includes cms, health insurance providers, medical associations, consumer groups, purchasers (including employer group representatives) and other quality collaboratives working together to recommend core sets of measures by clinical area to assess the quality of american health care.  bcbsa is a voting member in the cqmc and recently voted in opposition to including the hospital-wide, 30-day, all-cause unplanned readmission (hwr) rate for mips eligible clinician groups measure in the aco/pcmh measure set. bcbsa instead voted in support of ncqa’s plan all-cause readmission (pcr) measure. health plans use the pcr measure more widely as it is an ncqa accreditation requirement. additionally, discussion with the cqmc workgroup included identification that the pcr measure is more robust and broader than the hwr measure. for example, the pcr measure includes patients 18 and older while the hwr measure only includes patients 65 and older.  the risk standardized, all-cause unplanned admissions for multiple chronic conditions for acos measure was not reviewed by the cqmc aco/pcmh workgroup. cqmc members can bring measures forward for review, yet this measure was not identified for review with the  workgroup by any of the members. therefore, in support of the cqmc aims and objectives, bcbsa opposes the inclusion of this admission measure. bcbsa recommends that cms align with the aco/pcmh core measure set in support of the cqmc aims outlined above.
56: removal of the web interface reporting option: cms proposes to abruptly end the use of the web interface reporting mechanism, a tool that has been used since the mssp’s inception. removing this option for all acos with no notice is ill timed and unfair. we urge cms to restore this reporting mechanism in the final rule.
57: • maintain web interface for quality reporting: as a large aco representing more than 1500 providers across many different electronic medical record (emr) platforms, our participating providers have varying degrees of emr integration. over the past four years baycare has chosen to use the web interface for quality reporting as it allows us to manually audit all charts of the patients sampled, even those where we do not have emr integration. we would support either direct reporting that limited sampling to emr-integrated providers or continuing the option of reporting through the web interface. eliminating the web portal option without limiting sampling to emr-integrated providers would prevent reported quality measures from accurately reflecting the care provided in our full aco network.
58: maintain either the current quality performance standard or the quality reporting process: increasing the performance standard to the 40th percentile while changing the mechanics of how we report could have a compounding effect and undermine the successful momentum created by the mssp program. baycare would support either reporting changes or increased quality standards, but implementing both changes simultaneously would be harmful to many highperforming acos.
59: dear administrator verma, our accountable care organization (aco) writes to you to urge cms to not finalize the quality proposals released in the 2021 medicare physician fee schedule rule. these changes are significant and touch every aspect of quality improvement efforts from reporting quality data, tracking measure performance, and how acos are evaluated and scored for both the medicare shared savings program (mssp) and merit-based incentive payment system (mips). the changes come at a very challenging time, when our aco and the health care industry as a whole continue to navigate the great uncertainty resulting from the covid-19 global health pandemic. we urge cms to not finalize these proposals and continue to work with acos to adapt the quality measurement and assessment process. there are multiple concerns with the proposed aco quality changes. first, replacing the current domain-based quality scoring approach with an all or nothing standard is a significant change that will have a big impact on aco performance. secondly, drastically reducing the number of quality measures from 23 to six de-emphasizes quality and will create a performance standard that may not be truly representative of an aco's actual quality improvement efforts. thirdly, abruptly removing the web interface as a reporting mechanism will have a big impact on acos' ability to get credit for their true quality efforts. cms should continue to offer the web interface as an option and over time allow additional reporting options to those acos who would be ready to implement, such as registry or electronic health record (ehr) reporting. additionally, moving to the alternative reporting options cms has provided through the proposed apm performance pathway (app) would cause many acos to have to pay for registries and/or ehr upgrades and dashboards to capture the correct data to be able to report to cms. finally, there are remaining questions regarding how the aco would report the data for non-medicare and non-aco patient data, which is required when reporting using a registry or ehr. this could cause acos to have to revisit contracts and could raise legal concerns as the aco does not typically have access to non-aco patient data. finally, we also have deep concerns with cms's proposal to remove the pay-for-reporting year currently provided to first time acos as well as quality measures that are newly introduced or undergo significant changes. acos use the pay-for-reporting year as a time to get the correct processes and performance dashboards in place to be able to be successful in their quality improvement efforts. these are critical and removing them while still holding acos accountable for new quality measures, as an example, is unfair and will cause acos to hesitate to enter the program. acos are committed to providing high quality care to our patients and quality improvement is at the core of what we do. making these sweeping changes at this challenging time will disadvantage my aco and we urge cms to not finalize these proposed aco quality policies. sincerely, lysette cournoyer, director population health analytics baptist physician partners 841 prudential dr. ste 1450 jacksonville, fl 32207
60: ii. comment on shared savings program quality performance standard cms proposes to increase the level of quality performance that would be required for all acos to meet the medicare shared savings program (mssp) quality performance standard to the 40th percentile or above across all mips quality performance category scores. the previous standard was achieving the 30th percentile on one measure in each domain. additionally, the proposal includes a provision applicable to 2021 and subsequent performance years specifying that acos must submit quality data via the app to satisfactorily report on behalf of the eligible clinicians who bill under the tin of an aco participant for purposes of the mips quality performance category. cms proposes that to qualify for shared savings, an aco must meet the minimum savings rate requirements established for the track/level, meet the proposed quality performance standard described in the proposed rule, and otherwise maintain its eligibility to participate in the spp. for performance years beginning on or after january 1, 2021, if an aco that is otherwise eligible to share in savings meets the proposed quality performance standard, the aco will share in savings at the maximum sharing rate according to the applicable financial model (up to the performance payment limit). if the aco fails to meet the proposed quality performance standard, the aco would be ineligible to share in savings. recommendation: we do not support changing the quality measure minimum threshold from the 30th to 40th percentile. achieving shared savings is very difficult work. the 30th percentile is currently difficult to achieve for some measures due to small numbers and tight benchmarks. an aco could have a high quality score and score below the 40th percentile on just one measure, and the way cms has written the proposed change, having one measure below the 40th percentile could make the aco ineligible for shared savings. for the 2019 performances year, our aco had an overall quality score of 96%; we also scored a 40th percentile or lower on 2 of the 23 measures. if this proposed change was in place for the 2019 performance year, our aco would have been ineligible for shared savings, even with a significantly high score. the current corrective action plan is the appropriate next step when an aco does not score well in quality. we do not support a penalty of losing all shared savings opportunities for a year where quality performance does not meet the minimum attainment, as ngacos already take on a high amount of risk.
61: i. comment on quality and reporting requirements cms proposes to revise the medicare shared savings program (mssp) quality performance standard effective for performance year 2021 and subsequent performance years. according to cms, the new app would streamline reporting requirements for mssp acos and would create a complementary path to the mips value pathways. under this proposal, the number of measures acos would be scored on would decrease from 23 to 6, and the number of measures on which acos would be required to actively report would be reduced from 10 to 3. acos would only need to report one set of quality metrics that would satisfy the reporting requirements under both mips and the mssp. the four categories in the proposed app  our mission is to improve health and well-being in partnership with our members, patients and community. framework would be weighted as follows: quality: 50%; promoting interoperability: 30%; improvement activities: 20%; and cost: 0%. recommendation: our organization includes providers who participates in the mips program and the next generation aco model. the next generation aco model follows the same rules as the mssp acos. as a next generation aco, we appreciate that medicare is proposing to reduce the number of quality measures for acos. this would reduce the reporting burden and allow acos to focus on a select number of quality measures. a lower number of measures also means that there is more weight placed on only a few quality measures. we have reviewed the proposed quality measures and agree with continuing to report on the proposed preventive health and at risk population measures. however, we would request more information on the cahps measures such as will the current 2019/2020 cahps measures continue in 2021? healthpartnersthrough its park nicollet aco has participated in cmmi aco risk programs since 2012 and because of the subjective nature of the survey our overall patient experience domain score has varied significantly through the years. we believe part of this could be that the survey is lengthy, and not all of the questions apply to all of the patients, causing a low response rate to some of the questions that can skew the results. only 861 of our overall aco patients (~15,000) receive this survey and less than 400 of our patients usually complete the survey. the number of patients responding creates a challenge. it is difficult to implement changes to address all survey topics for all patients as well as rely on the patient to recall what was recently discussed. we are also concerned about the number of surveys that our patients receive as it is our organizations current practice to send all patients a short experience survey after each visit at healthpartners.  healthpartners agrees that patient experience is an important part of the triple aim to evaluate and would like to continue including these measures in quality reporting, however we are concerned that reducing the number of overall measures puts disproportionate weight on the cahps for aco survey results for all the reasons noted above; we are not fully confident that the results of the survey reflect our aco patients experience.  the proposed 2021 quality measures also include 2 claims measures from the care coordination/patient safety domain. our aco would also like to provide feedback on these 2 measures as 2 of the 6 proposed measures. we have found that we have also had a lot of variation for our results related to the risk standardized 30-day readmissions measure. healthpartners has found that the benchmarks for the claims based measures are very tight. our numerator and denominator are relatively small, which means that if a few additional patients are admitted or readmitted (depending on the measure) our results can easily swing from passing to failing. we would suggest evaluating how the benchmarks are set for the claims-based measures.....
62: iii. comment on proposal to remove aco overlap patients from qp denominator in the proposed rule, cms specifies that beneficiaries who are prospectively attributed to an apm entity will be excluded from the attribution-eligible beneficiary count for any other apm entity, when that beneficiary would be ineligible to be added to the other apm entity’s attributed beneficiary list. that is, cms would remove prospectively aligned beneficiaries from the denominator when calculating the thresholds. the preamble to the proposed rule states that “the effect of this proposed policy would be to remove such prospectively attributed beneficiaries from the denominators when calculating threshold scores for apm entities or individual eligible clinicians in advanced apms that align beneficiaries retrospectively, thereby preventing dilution of the threshold score for the apm entity or individual eligible clinician in an advanced apm that uses retrospective attribution.” recommendation: our aco agrees that the aco overlap patients could be removed from the qp denominator. healthpartners/park nicollet accountable care organization llc is a part of an aco coalition which has submitted feedback regarding freezing the qp thresholds in 2021 instead of increasing these thresholds. we did not see this addressed in the proposed and so we are including our feedback letter on this topic.
63: iv. proposal to modify the cahps for mips quality reporting cms notes that the mssp extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy applies for the cy 2020 performance period due to the covid-19 pandemic. as a result cms proposes to waive the requirement to field the cahps survey and will grant all acos full credit for the cahps measures. recommendation: we ask that for performance year 2020, the requirement for acos to administer/report cahps has been waived, and will receive full credit for cahps reporting. recommend to apply the same waiver to mips groups that elected to administer/report cahps, to create alignment amongst the programs. also, it’s noted the acos 2021 cahps measures will count as one score. recommend that all domains be scored as have historically, since there may only be 5 additional measures reported for acos. measuring all domains will then will continue the alignment between the aco and mips programs.
64: vii. sunset of the web interface cms proposes to eliminate the web interface reporting option starting with the cy 2021 reporting period. this option was previously available to groups and virtual groups of 25 clinicians or more. cms indicates that the use of the web interface has declined significantly over the past two performance periods. furthermore, cms proposes to eliminate the requirement for mssp participants to report quality measure data via the web interface, and the vast majority of web interface users were in the mssp. we describe the mssp quality reporting changes elsewhere in this advisory. lastly, cms notes that the web interface requirements were significantly more stringent than the other mips reporting options, and that nine out of the 10 measures included in the web interface would remain available in the mips using one of the other mips reporting options. recommendation: retiring the web interface at this time would create an undue hardship and financial burden on practices, as currently still operating in covid-19 pandemic state. it also reduces flexibility in reporting as to what works well for one practice versus another. the consensus among industry analysts is that most electronic health records have not been able to keep up with the changing requirements of the mips program, and that qcdrs are not able to report all categories of the program. it would be detrimental that cms provides a list of all mvp measures/specifications to all electronic medical record vendors and qcdrs early on, so that all emrs and qcdrs have the ability to report in a timely manner. the administrative burden associated with moving to a new reporting mechanism involves allocating staffing resources to redesign care process and work flows, at the potential expense of the overall care experience for patients in order to meet the reporting requirements. also, it states on page 50279 of the rule, that the traditional mips option will continue to be available for 2021. therefore, we recommend that the web interface remain a reporting option in 2021 to allow practices time to convert to a new reporting mechanism, with the ability to test out the new reporting mechanism alongside the web interface. this would allow groups to continue submissions as have historically and would ease reporting burden during a national pandemic. some of the reporting options offered, such as ecqms and mips cqms, require all payer data be submitted. this is a significant change from reporting medicare ffs only through the web interface, as the denominator has been greatly increased, and creates unknown risk in how a practice may score under the new reporting method. therefore, we again recommend that groups be allowed to report two ways for 2021 – through the web interface and another option chosen. this is not much different than what cms allows today, reporting the category components through different reporting options and keeping the highest score across sources.
66: modifications to the extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy for py 2020 proposal: cms is seeking comment on an alternative quality scoring approach for acos under the extreme and uncontrollable circumstances policy. the alternative approach would use the highest score of an aco’s 2020 or their 2019 quality performance score, for those acos that completely report quality data for 2020. for acos that do not complete quality reporting, they would receive the 2020 aco mean quality score. comment: bilhpn supports the alternative quality scoring approach for the 2020 performance year. it is unlikely aco’s can accurately measure the impact the coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19) will have on 2020 quality reporting. permitting acos who report quality to use the highest of their 2020 or 2019 quality performance score provides them the needed flexibilities during this unprecedented time.
67: quality performance to determine mssp shared savings and shared losses proposal: cms proposes that if an aco that is otherwise eligible to share in savings meets the proposed quality performance standard, that aco will share in savings at the maximum sharing rate according to the applicable financial model, up to the performance payment limit. comment: bilhpn supports the proposal to share savings at the maximum sharing rate if an aco meets the proposed quality performance standard. eliminating the current savings rate calculation will be beneficial to acos given the higher quality performance standard that is being proposed. however, bilhpn is concerned with the quality performance standard as it is currently proposed. bilhpn recommends that cms decrease the 40th percentile threshold to a 30th percentile threshold to allow acos to become acquainted with mips reporting. cms could revisit increasing the performance threshold to the 40th percentile in future years.
69: apm performance pathway for shared savings program acos proposal: cms proposes to revise the mssp quality performance standard by replacing the current quality measure set with the apm performance pathway (app). additionally, cms proposed that acos would only need to report one set of quality metrics (via the app) that would satisfy the reporting requirements under both mssp and mips. comment: bilhpn supports reducing the quality measure set from 23 to six and eliminating the cms web interface as a collection type. furthermore, bilhpn agrees with cms that using a single methodology to measure quality performance under both the mssp and merit-based incentive payment system (mips) would reduce reporting burden and allow acos to track a smaller set of measures under one scoring methodology.
72: quality performance standard the current quality performance standard requires accountable care organizations (acos) to meet minimum attainment (defined as 30 percent or the 30th percentile of the performance benchmark for pay-for-performance (p4p) measures) on at least one measure in each domain to be eligible to share in any savings generated. in the cy 2021 proposed rule, cms proposes that acos must achieve a quality performance score “equivalent to the 40th percentile or above across all merit-based incentive payment system (mips) quality performance category scores.” the language used to describe this proposal is so different from the previous standard that the proposal has sparked debate among our members as to its application and makes it difficult to meaningfully comment. is the achievement of a quality performance score “across all mips quality performance scores” meant to apply across all domains in the aggregate, or across each individual domain at the 40th percentile? as acos prepare for the upcoming year, the fah urges cms to clarify its intent.
